Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Oxide Film Effects on Dislocation Nucleation -- Implications to Structure/Property Relations
Award.AbstractNarration:
TECHNICAL SUMMARY

This project involves a combination of in situ nanoindentation studies in a Transmission Electron Microsocpe (TEM) with in situ measurements of electrical conductance between tip and sample. It is now possible to measure small conductance changes induced by dislocation nucleation, while simultaneously measuring nanoindentation curves. This powerful measurement capability will address the role of native oxide film formation on nanoscale mechanical properties. This effect is very important because as sizes scale downwards, the oxide role is inadequately understood but of relevance to a large variety of technological issues such as stress corrosion cracking, fretting fatigue, mechanically-assisted dielectric breakdown, fatigue of Micro-Electro-Mechanical Systems (MEMS), fracture toughness of nanostructures, MEMS tribology and wear and yielding in general. Model thin-film systems comprised of metal or semiconductor films coated with oxide overlayers will be used to explore fundamentals of the early stages of dislocation nucleation at or near surfaces, i.e. to establish the critical structure-property relationships at the nanometer scale. In particular, understanding the indentation size effect at very small length scales is unresolved in most metallic systems since the image forces associated with native oxide films have usually been ignored. By measuring conductive contacts during deformation of oxide-covered thin metallic films, simultaneously with load-displacement output, dislocation scale events can be directly monitored.

NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY

The proposed work has the potential to impact an unusually wide range of scientific communities because it is fundamentally inter-disciplinary. It includes instrumental, scientific, and technological advances that will be of interest to the communities doing research on electron microscopy, electronic transport in nanostructures and atomistic simulation of mechanical properties of materials. The proposed research is of very significant value technologically. Oxide film formation affects mechanical properties at small length scales and plays and important role in areas as diverse as stress corrosion cracking, fretting fatigue, mechanically assisted dielectric breakdown, fatigue of MEMS, fracture toughness of nanostructures, MEMS tribology and wear. These are core issues in many areas of nanotechnology that will be immediately impacted by the proposed research. The PIs have an excellent record of inclusion of undergraduate students in their research, an effort that will be aggressively continued during the duration of this award. These students are funded through various programs such as the UMN Undergraduate Research Opportunities Program, NSF REU programs, directed research for credit, etc., and have been involved in all aspects of the activities of the PI?s research groups.

Institution.Name: University of Minnesota-Twin Cities
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MINNESOTA

POR.DRECONTENT:
This NSF award to two investigators in the University of Minnesota’s Department of Chemical Engineering and Materials Science focused on the understanding of the mechanical properties of very thin film metals coated with oxides. Such metallic thin films are used extensively in science and technology, for instance as the interconnects that connect transistors in integrated circuits in computers, and in new technologies based on miniaturization of mechanical components and machines (otherwise known as MEMS – micro-electro-mechanical systems). Two major issues that arise in such applications are that (a) at such extremely small sizes the mechanical properties (e.g. strength and elasticity) become significantly modified, and (b) the metal surfaces can oxidize in air to form overlayers with very different mechanical properties than the metals. The purpose of this project was to understand, in considerable detail, the effects of such ultrathin oxide overlayers on the mechanical properties of metals on very small size scales.

In terms of intellectual merit, the major gains from the work were in the understanding of exactly how oxide overlayers effect elastic and plastic response on length scales of around a few tens of nanometers. To do this the investigators employed a method known as nanoindentation, where a very small hard tip is controllably pressed into the surface of the metal/oxide films and the mechanical response measured. In this particular work, in addition to measuring force against displacement, the investigators also measured resistance to flow of electrical current through the nanocontact. Due to the fact that the metals conduct electricity and the thin oxide overlayers do not, it was possible to distinguish between events occurring in the metal related to defects, and events occurring in the overlayer due to cracking. Similar experiments were also performed on the very technologically important semiconductor silicon, providing important new information on how silicon deforms at very small sizes. Metal films prepared in this work were also used in the field of plasmonics, where it was shown that a number of proposed devices could benefit from the use of metal layers with certain defects eliminated.

In terms of broader impact of the work, this award enabled the education and training of three graduate students and a post-doctoral researcher, two of which have graduated with PhD degrees and have entered the workforce. The principal investigators on the project were also active in a number of outreach activities, including interactions with the public through the Science Museum of Minnesota and in the classroom with 7th and 8th grade students at Lake Harriett Community School in Minneapolis, MN.     


Last Modified: 01/31/2013
Modified by: Christopher Leighton

Such metallic thin films are used extensively in science and technology, for instance as the interconnects that connect transistors in integrated circuits in computers, and in new technologies based on miniaturization of mechanical components and machines (otherwise known as MEMS – micro-electro-mechanical systems). Two major issues that arise in such applications are that (a) at such extremely small sizes the mechanical properties (e.g. strength and elasticity) become significantly modified, and (b) the metal surfaces can oxidize in air to form overlayers with very different mechanical properties than the metals. In terms of intellectual merit, the major gains from the work were in the understanding of exactly how oxide overlayers effect elastic and plastic response on length scales of around a few tens of nanometers. To do this the investigators employed a method known as nanoindentation, where a very small hard tip is controllably pressed into the surface of the metal/oxide films and the mechanical response measured.
